title: Will Juan Hernandez win Honduras' upcoming presidential election?
possible_answers: Yes, with more than 45% of the popular vote
Yes, with between 38% and 45% of the popular vote, inclusive
Yes, with more than 27% but less than 38% of the vote
Yes, with 27% or less of the popular vote
correct_answer: Yes, with between 38% and 45% of the popular vote, inclusive
preds:
https://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Whos-Who-in-Honduras-General-Elections-20171120-0002.html
"The top three candidates, according to most surveys, are Hernandez, Nasralla and Medrano. In October, Encuestadora Paradigma ranked them at 42.5 percent, 19.8 percent and nine percent respectively. Meanwhile, Moreno Research placed the same candidates at 46 percent, 23 percent and 12 percent."
and
https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/23/opinion/honduras-juan-orlando-hernandez-election.html?_r=0
"It’s possible that Mr. Nasralla would win a free and fair election, as there is plenty of opposition to Mr. Hernández’s re-election — nearly two-thirds of Hondurans oppose re-election. But Mr. Hernández and his allies control the much-protested ballot-counting process, the election oversight commission, the army — which under Honduran law moves the ballots — and all appeals processes. Given his total control over the election process, we can’t expect him and his corrupt manipulators to allow a free and fair election to decide their fate."
No major changes in thinking since previous forecasts ... just less time (as the weeks pass by) that some major circuit-breaking event will disrupt JOH's likely re-election with 48-50% of the vote.

I concocted a model that is least favorable to JOH, within the confines of being in accord with the two poll results considered (Sep Gallup, Oct Paradigma). 
 The key to this model is splitting the undecideds as follows: 1/2 goes for Nasrallah, 1/4 for JOH and 1/4 for the rest. I also modelled stochastically the turnouts, separately for each bloc (assuming them to be highest for the challenger, lowest for the incumbent). In the end this yielded an expected margin for JOH of only 4.7%. The answer still have not moved much from my previous, more lopsided model! But, interestingly, a tiny chance emerges for JOH to lose in this scenario.
 So I'm putting that in, just to exhibit my contrarian streak...

"The top three candidates, according to most surveys, are Hernandez, Nasralla and Medrano. In October, Encuestadora Paradigma ranked them at 42.5 percent, 19.8 percent and nine percent respectively. Meanwhile, Moreno Research placed the same candidates at 46 percent, 23 percent and 12 percent."

Read a commentary article - apparently there is a polling blackout in the month before the election ... which explains the lack of polling data.  I guess that means we can all try to over-interpret the single Cid/Gallup poll! Nudging the margin of JOH's victory up a little based on increasing concerns about pro-government election rigging.  I don't think JOH will _need_ to rig the election to win, but I think there is advantage to JOH in having a clear election victory. Also, reconsidering the Cid/Gallop poll (see, over-interpreting!) ...
Let's assume it shows JOH with a 15% margin over his nearest competitor, and that is an accurate poll.  Mathematically, it is _very_ hard to envision a scenario where, in a 3-horse race, a candidate can win with a 15% margin, and _not_ also get 45.1% or more of the vote. Finally, JOH's support is roughly the same as the summed support of the other 2 main candidates. Yes, the poll might not be accurate, and yes, there are some minor parties running, and yes, the 15% margin in those polled might not represent a 15% margin in those who actually turn up to vote ... but it certainly does help triangulate on a result with JOH getting roughly 50%.

Assuming support levels unchanged from the Sep Cid/Gallup results: 37%,22%,17%,2%
http://criterio.hn/2017/09/21/partido-liberal-libre-descalifican-encuesta-cid-gallup/
Model now  disregards the undecided/nonresponse portion altogether, and proportions the 4-way numbers to 100% total; the large change in the result, versus my prior outcome when the undecideds was not taken out from the total, shows the crucial impact of what happens with that portion.
Thanks @Ken_Barns and @ZFekete for the polling data that I was unable to find.. I must be using the wrong search criteria... (Honduras Presidential election polls).
My current baseline forecast, assuming support levels unchanged from the Sep Cid/Gallup results
Another toy model prediction, this one assuming that half the undecideds would go for Nasralla
This is from a toy model prediction, taking a combined opposition bloc from the two candidates polling 2nd and 3rd place in the Sep Cid/Gallup poll.

Based on sketchy polling data putting JOH at 43-45% of the vote, but combined vote of the other two main candidates at 30-35% ... thus 20% are "Undecided/Other".  Presumably a few of those will peel off in JOH's direction (or else stay home, which will have the same effect on JOH's percentage of those who turn out). CAVEAT: 
I am heavily banking on "minor" candidates having a marginal vote; essentially I am treating this as a 3-horse race.  The last time the _combined_ minor candidate vote was more than 5% in a presidential election was in 1985.
revised for two Sep polls (Cid/Gallup & Encuestadora Paradmigna)
crude initial model, based on May poll

So a couple of hours reading around various sources ... Are all the results possible?  Yes - barely.  This is a single sitting election, where the candidate with the greatest primary vote wins.  No run-offs, no preferences, no need for a majority. Most recent polling I could find is here: http://criterio.hn/2017/09/21/partido-liberal-libre-descalifican-encuesta-cid-gallup/ A result of "Yes, less than 27%" seems the least likely.  Last election had 4 significant candidates getting at least 13% of the vote each (all the other candidates combined got <0.7% of the vote).  This election will have 3 significant candidates.  I have real difficulty seeing how the votes could be distributed in a 3-way election such that the winning candidate has 27% (or less!) of the vote.  In short, a JOH with less than 27% is a JOH who loses.  Still, "stranger things" and all that ... TOTAL "Yes, <27%" = 1%
(And I would round this to 0% if a fusion between the Alliance and the PL occurs - see below.) Also unlikely is JOH losing the election.  However, having the Liberal Party (PL) join the Libre/PINU Alliance is not inconceivable.  If that happens, the Alliance might not just fuse the two votes, but also appear to have a better chance of winning, and thus pull in further votes that otherwise might be "wasted" on smaller parties, or where voters might not have turned up at all.  Highly unlikely though:  perhaps 5% chance of the Alliance expanding and, if so, perhaps a 60% chance of winning the election. If no fusion occurs, then the PL and Alliance will almost certainly lose ... but let's give a token chance (3%?) that one of the Alliance or PL wins _without_ a fusion. TOTAL "No" = 6%.  
(This will fall with time if a fusion between the Alliance and PL does _not_ occur.) For the remaining outcomes (JOH wins with 27.01%+) that leaves 93%.  That seems about right.  But how many votes will he get?  The poll has JOH sitting at 37%.  This same poll (Cid/Gallup) under-counted JOH's result in 2013 by about 10% in its September and October 2013 polls.  That turned neck-and-neck polling into a comfortable 37% to 29% win over the Libre candidate.  That 2013 polling also under-counted the PL by 5% or so, and was reasonably on the mark for the two candidates/parties who now make up the Alliance.  Basically the 15-20% of "I don't knows" in the polling defected to JOH or the PL in the election.   I have no reason to suspect that this election will be any more or less free and fair than the previous presidential election in 2013.  (And boy, am I aware of regretting making _that_ assumption for the Venezuelan gubernatorial elections!!) So that puts the middling result somewhere in the upper end of the 38-45% band, which would make 45% more likely than 27-38%.  Also, keeping in mind a 3-way race, it is really tricky to win with only 38% (or less) of the vote.  I'm just going to guess on how narrow or wide the distribution of results are, so ... "Yes, 27-38%" = 16%
"Yes, 38-45%" = 42%
"Yes, 45%+" = 35% Of course, all of this is assuming:
a)  The Cid/Gallup poll is as (in)accurate as they were in 2013; this means that further polls might swing my forecasts.
b)  The vote were happening tomorrow.  I'll have to factor in some fudge factor for volatility, which will count down if nothing drastic happens between now and the end of November.   Bah - I'll get to that tomorrow ...

Hard to come up with a number given the new moving parts in this election. For example, I read that 2/3rds of Hondurans don't support the idea of a President having 2 terms but according to polls, people support Hernandez anyway. 
Hernandez won in 2013 with 36.89% of the vote beating liberal parties split between 3 candidates. 
This election has an alliance headed by Nasralla who got 13.43% in the 2013 race running with Castro (the wife of the deposed leader in 2009) who got 28.78% in the 2013 race.  I'm not finding polls other than the one in April and the August CID/Gallup. Anyone have information out there?

This guy was once a student of mine, but we haven't been in touch for several years.  In situations like this, I always have a hard time stifling my personal feelings and sticking with the probabilities.  Not sure yet how well I'm doing it this time, especially since he is getting mixed reviews at home.   Never, by the way, fly into TGU unless (a) you absolutely have to, and (b) you are good and drunk or otherwise sedated for the landing.  Feels like a barrel roll is, if not imminent, at least not out of the question.
